Propaganda is a form of communication to distribute information

Investment or investing means that an asset is bought, or that money is put into a bank to get a future interest from it

The border between two regions is a line, where one region is next to the other

The word "information" is used in many different ways

Biology is the science of life and living things, and their evolution

Measurement is a process that uses numbers to describe things based on what we can observe about them

MERIDIAN
A meridian is an imaginary line of longitude drawn along the surface of the earth from the North Pole to the South Pole.

The inch (abbreviation in, prime symbol ") is a unit of length in the Imperial System and the United States Customary Units.

EARTH
The Earth, our world, is the third planet from the Sun

Length is a property of a thing that can be measured

The second (symbol: s) is a unit of time, and one of the seven SI base units

An abbreviation is a shorter way to write a word or phrase

VACUUM

EQUATOR
The equator is a line which is not real drawn around a sphere or planet, such as the Earth

The rifle is a gun with a stock to brace against the shoulder and a barrel with twisting grooves

CAMOUFLAGE
Camouflage is a visual disguise

Australia is a country in the Southern Hemisphere between the Pacific Ocean and the Indian Ocean

A desert biome is an area that receives less than 25cm (about 9.8 inches) of rainfall a year

November is the eleventh and penultimate (second-last) month of the year in the Gregorian calendar, coming between October and December

A mountain is a natural rise of the Earth's surface that usually has a "summit" (or "top")

IBERIAN PENINSULA
The Iberian Peninsula, or Iberia, is the southwest part of Europe

MURCIA
Murcia is the capital of the autonomous community of Murcia, in Spain, and its biggest city, with a population of 410,000 in the city and more than 740,000 in the metropolitan area

NORTH AMERICA
North America is a continent in the Northern and Western halves of Earth

KING
A king is a man who rules a country, because of inheritance

BASQUE COUNTRY
The Basque Country (called Euskal Herria by its inhabitants) is a region in South-West Europe, that is contained within the borders of France and Spain.

The Visigoths (Western Goths) were one of two main branches of the Goths

Tenerife is one of the seven Canary Islands

The capital city (or just capital) is a city where the central government of a country, or part of a country, such as a state, province, or county, is.

CREOLE LANGUAGE
A creole language (or a creole) is a language that comes from a pidgin.[1] Creoles seem very similar to each other, even if they come from different languages.[2] There is not a widely accepted theory that explains why this happens.

The epicenter or epicentre is the point on the Earth's surface that is directly above the hypocenter or focus

PARAGUAY
Paraguay (officially the Republic of Paraguay or Republica del Paraguay) is a small country in South America

The Caribbean or Caribbean Area (Dutch: Cariben or Caraiben, French: Carabe or more commonly Antilles; Spanish: Caribe) is a region of the Americas

El Salvador (Spanish: Repblica de El Salvador) is the smallest and most densely populated country in Central America

Antananarivo is the capital city of Madagascar

Tax is money that people are forced to pay to the government.

HERM
Herm is the smallest of the Channel Islands that is open to the public.

Sark is one of the Channel Islands

ALDERNEY
Alderney is one of the Channel Islands in the English Channel between England and France

The English Channel is a body of water that separates the island of Great Britain from the rest of Europe

Brecqhou is one of the Channel Islands

ORTAC
Ortac is a small uninhabited islet about 5&#160;km West of the coast of Alderney near to the islet of Burhou

JETHOU
Jethou is a small island that is part of the Bailiwick of Guernsey in the Channel Islands

CREVICHON
Crevichon is an islet off Herm, immediately to the north of Jethou, in the Channel Islands

BURHOU
Burhou (pronounced bu-ROO) is a small island approximately 1.4 miles (2.25&#160;km) northwest of Alderney that is part of the Channel Islands

Luxembourg City is the capital city of Luxembourg

A parliamentary system of government means that the executive branch of government must have the direct or indirect support of the parliament

PRONOUN
A pronoun is traditionally called a part of speech in grammar (but many modern linguists, experts in linguistics, call it a special type of noun[1]) In English, pronouns are words such as me, she, his, them, herself, each other, it, what.

SENTENCE
A sentence is a group of words that are put together to mean something

HUMAN
A human is a member of the species Homo sapiens which means 'wise man' in Latin.[1]

PREPOSITION
Prepositions are words or word groups which begin a noun phrase with more than one word

PLURAL
The quantitatory descriptor plural is the form of a noun that serves to indicate that the quantity of that noun is larger than one.

IDEA
When a person thinks of something, that which he/she thinks about is called an "idea"

QUALITY
Quality is how good something is

PARTICIPLE

NAME
Name is a word (or a set of words) given to things and people.

ADVERB
An adverb is a word used to tell more about a verb, and it almost always answers the questions how?, when?, where?, how often?, and in what way?

OBJECT (GRAMMAR)
An object in grammar is the target of an action, and occurs in any sentence with a transitive verb

SUFFIX
A suffix is a few letters put at the end of a word to change its meaning

INFINITIVE
The infinitive is a verb form

ARTICLE (GRAMMAR)
An article is a word that comes before a noun

ADJECTIVE
An adjective is a kind of word (a part of speech) that modifies (describes) a noun

SINGULAR
Singular is a form of the noun that shows that there is only one

The Cretaceous period was the longest period in the Phanerozoic eon, lasting 80 million years from 145 to 66 million years ago (mya)

A twig is a small, thin branch.[1] Twigs are very important in telling apart trees, shrubs and vines, especially in wintertime.

HABITAT
A habitat describes the place where many animals or plants live

NUTRIENT
A nutrient is either a chemical element or compound used in an organism's metabolism or physiology

NORSE MYTHOLOGY
Norse or Scandinavian mythology is the belief and legends of the Scandinavian people

HELMET
A helmet is a hard or cushioned hat which is worn to protect a person's head

REDWOOD
The Redwood trees are a subfamily (Sequoioideae) within the family Cupressaceae, the cypress trees

MYTHOLOGY
Mythology is the collection of myths for a culture

GROVE (NATURE)
A grove is a small group of trees with little or no undergrowth

ARBORIST
An arborist is a person that studies trees.

BODY LANGUAGE
Body language means the way humans show their feelings (communicate) with their bodies

TOUCH
Touch is one of the five main senses that animals have

SENSORY SYSTEM
The sensory system is the way animals find out about their nearby environment

SOMATOSENSORY SYSTEM
The 'somatosensory system' is a sensory system that detects experiences labelled as touch or pressure, temperature (warm or cold), pain (including itch and tickle) and those that belong to proprioception

CLOTHING
Clothing is foreign fabric, apparel or items which is made to cover part of the human body

WRITING
Writing is the act of recording language on a visual medium using a set of symbols

SIGN LANGUAGE
A sign language is a way of communicating by using the hands and other parts of the body

ARTS
The arts are a large part of culture, and the word means much more than "art"

OLFACTION
Olfaction is the sense of smell

VOICE
A voice is used when someone speaks or sings

HAIRSTYLE
A hairstyle is the way hair is cut and styled

SOUND
We can define a sound wave as a disturbance which travels through some medium

NOTE (MUSIC)
In music, a note is a small bit of sound, similar to a syllable in speaking a language

RHYTHM
Rhythm refers to the length of time between each major "beat", or accent, such as in a piece of music

INTONATION (LINGUISTICS)
In linguistics, intonation is variation of pitch while speaking which is not used to distinguish words

SIGN
A sign is something you see (or hear) which means something

GESTURE
A gesture is a form of nonverbal communication

EPIDEMIOLOGY

STOCK MARKET

ECONOMICS

INTEREST
Interest is the cost for borrowing money or the payment for lending money

EMOTICON
An emoticon (pronunciation: /motkn/) is a written symbol, often as 2 or 3 punctuation characters, that stands for the writer's mood or facial expression

HAPPINESS

Fear is an emotion much like anxiety

HEREDITY
Heredity is the passing of traits (characteristics) from parents to offspring

MASS MEDIA

CENSORSHIP
Censorship is when certain facts changed or left out on purpose

DESIGN
Design is a visual look or a shape given to a certain object, in order to make it more attractive, make it more comfortable or to improve another characteristic

Central Europe is the region around the Alps and Carpathian Mountains lying between the areas of Eastern and Western Europe

COMMAND ECONOMY
A command economy, or a planned economy, is an economic system where the main economic decisions (such as allocating scarce resources like labour, capital, soil and natural resources) are taken by a central body; which is usually the government

The torso is the part of the human body where the limbs are attached

Jewellery (or jewelry) refers to any clothing accessory that is worn as a decoration.

A glove is a piece of clothing that covers a hand

COSMETICS
Cosmetics (also called makeup, make up, or make-up) are products used to make the human body look different

ARM
An arm is a limb

BODY MODIFICATION
Body modification (or body alteration) is when a person changes their body in a way that lasts forever or for a long time

Anno Domini (Latin&#160;: "In the year of (our) Lord"[1]), shortened as AD or A.D., is used to refer to the years after the birth of Jesus

An umbrella is a hand tool that is used to stop rain from falling on a person

Jeans are a type of pants made from heavy, strong cotton material (fabric) called denim

Wool is the hair of certain mammals

EYEGLASSES
Eyeglasses (U.S), or spectacles (Brit.) are pieces of glass or clear plastic, called lenses, in a frame that holds them in front of someone's eyes.

Socks are often worn on a person's feet

COAT
A coat is a piece of clothing that is worn over a person's upper body

A leg is something used to support things; to hold them up

BOOT
A boot is a type of footwear that protects the foot and ankle

FASHION
Fashion mostly refers to the style of clothing worn at a particular time

CANE
A cane is stick from a piece of wood, or sometimes of metal

SHIRT
A shirt is a kind of cloth which is made to cover the chest and upper body

TEXTILE
Cloth, textile or fabric are similar names for manufactured clothing material or drapery

LOUSE
Lice (singular: louse), are wingless insects that live in hair

BODY PIERCING
Body piercing or just piercing is a form of body modification, where humans of either gender pierce their skin to put jewellery through the hole later

SHOE
A shoe is a type of footwear

SANDAL (FOOTWEAR)
Sandals are an open type of footwear, consisting of a sole held to the wearer's foot by straps or thongs passing over the instep and around the ankle

POLYESTER
Polyester is a type of man made material

PRIMATE
Primates are a group of mammals that contains all lemurs, monkeys, and apes including humans

PERFUME
Perfume is a liquid that gives people, things and rooms a good smell

SCARIFICATION
Scarification or cicatrization is a form of body modification, where a design or pattern is cut, etched or scratched into human skin to make a permanent scar

WALLET
A wallet is a small flat container, mostly of leather or fabric, that a person uses to hold cash, credit cards, identification cards, etc

HAT
A hat is a type of covering for the head

HEAT
Heat is a form of energy

STEAM ENGINE
A Steam engine is an engine which uses steam from boiling water to make it go

A magnet is a very special metal

ELECTRIC MOTOR
An electric motor changes electrical energy into mechanical movement

WINDMILL
A windmill is a type of engine

TURBINE
A turbine is an engine that turns fluid movement into energy.

FOUR-STROKE ENGINE
The four-stroke engine is an internal combustion engine

MACHINE
A machine is a thing that is created by people to make work easier.

LOCOMOTIVE
A locomotive is the part of a train that makes the train move

JET ENGINE
A jet engine is any engine that creates force by releasing a high speed jet of a liquid or a gas.

PISTON
In general, a piston is a lubricated sliding shaft that fits tightly inside the opening of a cylinder

INTERNAL COMBUSTION ENGINE
An internal combustion engine is an engine in which combustion, or the burning of fuel, occurs on the inside

CHEMICAL SUBSTANCE
A chemical substance is any material with a known chemical composition.[1] For example, water has the same properties and the same ratio of hydrogen to oxygen whether it came from a river or was made in a laboratory

COMBAT
Combat, or fighting, is purposeful violent conflict between two or more persons, groups or organizations, often intended to establish dominance over the opponent

The First Epistle of Peter is the sixtieth book in the Christian Bible, and the twenty-first in the New Testament.

DEVIL
In some religions, the devil is a bad spirit that tries to create problems for people

SKATEBOARD
A skateboard is a board (called a "deck") with four wheels put on under it

Gliders are aircraft which do not have a motor

A cart is a vehicle with two wheels and usually pulled by one horse

A balloon is a bag that is usually filled with gas

A fixed-wing aircraft, more often called an aeroplane or airplane is a kind of aircraft

A submarine (or Sub) is a vessel that goes under water

BICYCLE
A bicycle, or bike, is a small, human powered land vehicle with a seat, two wheels, two pedals, and a metal chain connected to cogs on the pedals and rear wheel

SAILBOAT
A sailboat, sailing boat or yacht is a boat that has sails

ICEBOAT
Iceboats are a type of boat that run on ice

FLEXIBILITY TRAINING
Flexibility training refers to developing a wide range of movement in a joint or series of joints that is attainable in a momentary effort with the help of a partner or a piece of equipment

Apprenticeship is a system of training people who are learning how to do a job which needs special skill

SKILL

A land mine (sometimes just called a "mine") is a weapon that is put on the ground or just underneath the ground so that it explodes when a person or vehicle goes by

A machine gun is a weapon that can fire one bullet after another as long as the trigger is pulled and there are bullets ready to fire

SHOTGUN
A shotgun is a type of gun

TORPEDO
The torpedo, is an explosive projectile weapon that moves by itself (using a propeller), launched above or below the water surface, that goes underwater toward a target, and made to explode when it hits a target or is near to it

A spear is a weapon used in Antiquity and the Middle Ages

ASTROLOGY
Astrology is a pseudoscience where some people believe the position of the planets and other heavenly bodies changes life on earth.[1] A person who does astrology as a job is called an astrologer.

JESUS
Jesus (born sometime between 7 and 4 BC/BCE, killed between 30 and 34 AD/CE[note 1] in Jerusalem), also known as Jesus Christ or Jesus of Nazareth, is the central figure of the Christian religion

PRESBYTERIANISM
Presbyterianism is a kind of Protestant Christianity

PURITANISM
The Puritans were a group of English-speaking Protestants in the 16th and 17th centuries

RECONCILIATION
In Christian theology, reconciliation is the process of repairing one's relationship with God

HERESY
Heresy is a word used by different religious groups, used to describe someone who has ideas that are different from what the group teaches

ANABAPTIST
Anabaptists are Protestant Christians of the Radical Reformation of 16th century Europe

2013 Calendar

IGLESIA NI CRISTO
The Iglesia ni Cristo (IPA: [igl. ni krist]; Filipino for Church of Christ), or INC, is a church which was made in the Philippines by Felix Manalo in 1914.[1] The INC says it was made by Jesus Christ

HEAVEN
Heaven is a concept of the afterlife (what happens after you die) in many religions

NICENE CREED
The Nicene Creed, Niceno-Constantinopolitan Creed or Icon/Symbol of the Faith, is the most widespread or ecumenical Christian statement of faith.

EUCHARIST
The Eucharist, also called holy communion, the sacrament, or the Lord's supper, is a kind of religious ritual in many Christian churches

SIGN OF THE CROSS
The sign of the cross is a physical gesture made by Catholics and other Christians

CHRISTADELPHIANS
The Christadelphians are a Christian denomination that developed in the United Kingdom and the United States in the 19th century

HOLY SPIRIT
The Holy Spirit, or Holy Ghost, is a part of the triune godhead (three in one God) of Christianity.

SUNDAY
Sunday is one of the seven days of the week

The Gospel of Matthew is a book of the Bible

ONENESS PENTECOSTALISM
Oneness Pentecostalism is a Protestant Christian movement

PRIEST
A priest or priestess is a person who is allowed to do religious rites

GOSPEL
The word gospel literally means "good news", since it narrates Jesus Christ's life and teaching, to invite anyone to believe that he was born to save the world from sin and make humans truly know God as a Father

ANOINTING OF THE SICK
Anointing of the Sick (Extreme Unction) is a sacrament or sacred action in Roman Catholicism and other Christian denominations

CONFIRMATION (CHRISTIANITY)
In Christianity, babies might be baptised when they were young

TRANSUBSTANTIATION
Transubstantiation is the belief of Catholics and some other Christian churches that the bread and wine that are eaten and drank at Mass becomes (changes into) the body and blood of Jesus, who Christians believe is the son of God.

CONSECRATION
Consecration is a special ceremony, usually religious, in which a person, or an object or a building is dedicated to a special purpose

UNITED KINGDOM OF GREAT BRITAIN AND IRELAND
The United Kingdom of Great Britain and Ireland was the formal name of the United Kingdom from 1 January 1801 until 12 April 1927

KINGDOM OF GREAT BRITAIN
The Kingdom of Great Britain, sometimes called the 'United Kingdom of Great Britain',[1] was a state in the British Isles in Western Europe, in existence from 1707 to 1800

SOUTHEAST
Southeast or south east is the direction halfway between south and east

ARCHAEOLOGY

AXE
An axe (or ax) is an ancient tool

DECAPITATION
Decapitation or beheading is the act of cutting off the head from the rest of the body of a living thing

KILLING
The act of killing a living thing can be said to have happened when an outside force, usually another life form, has done something to cause it to die.

In a country whose system of government is a monarchy, the ruler, or head of state, is decided by inheritance

WOLFGANG AMADEUS MOZART
Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart (January 27, 1756 - December 5, 1791) was an Austrian composer, instrumentalist, and music teacher

COUNT
A count is a nobleman in most of European countries, equivalent in rank to a British earl, whose wife is also still a "countess" (for lack of an Anglo-Saxon term)

BALLET
Ballet is a type of dance

SEXUAL INTERCOURSE
Animals that reproduce sexually use sexual intercourse to have offspring

EXECUTION
Execution is where state authorities kill someone for having committed an extremely serious crime, usually treason or especially terrible murders

READING
Reading is a way of getting information from something that is written

HAIRDRESSER
A hairdresser's job is to cut, in a certain style, female hair to change its look

SMALLPOX
Smallpox is a very bad disease with a high mortality rate

WIFE
A wife is a married woman

DENTISTRY
Dentistry is a specialty in medicine, which is practiced by a dentist

ARCHDUKE
The title of Archduke (feminine: Archduchess) (German: Erzherzog, feminine form: Erzherzogin) is a rank above Duke and under King

FRIENDSHIP
Friendship is having a good relationship with someone, called a friend

MORALITY
Morality is the concept of doing the right thing

CHARLES III OF SPAIN
Charles III of Spain (1716-1788) was a king of Spain and the oldest son of Philip V and Elisabeth Farnese

Tuberculosis, or TB for short, is an infectious disease caused by bacteria

Pope Damasus II (Latin: Damasus Secundus; died August 9, 1048), born Poppo, was a German priest of the Roman Catholic Church and the 152nd Pope for only 24 days from July 17 to August 9, 1048.[1]

Otto I the Great (November 23 912  May 7 973), son of Henry I the Fowler, king of the Germans, and Matilda of Ringelheim, was Duke of the Saxons, King of the Germans and Holy Roman Emperor.

BALTIC STATES
Baltic states are three countries in Northern Europe at the eastern side of the Baltic Sea and at the southern side of Gulf of Finland

The Oder-Neisse line (named after the Oder and Neisse rivers) is the border between Germany and Poland since the end of the Second World War

MARGRAVE
A Margrave (German: Markgraf) is a German nobleman.

CITY-STATE

MINISTER-PRESIDENT
A minister-president (German: Ministerprsident) is the head of government in a number of European countries or subnational governments, who presides over the council of ministers

TREATY OF VERSAILLES
The Treaty of Versailles was a treaty to make peace between the five nations, France, Germany, Britain, Austria-Hungary and the United States after World War I

GERMAN EMPIRE
The German Empire ("Deutsches Reich" or "Deutsches Kaiserreich" in the German language) is the name for a group of German countries from January 18 1871 to November 9 1918

SILESIA
Silesia (Polish: lsk; German: Schlesien; Latin: Silesia; Silesian: lnsk) is a historical region of Poland

DUKE
A Duke is someone part of nobility.[1] In monarchies, like the UK, the title has legal status, and is inherited in the male line.

Rhineland-Palatinate (German: 'Rheinland-Pfalz') is one of 16 states (German: Bundeslnder) of Germany

A seat belt is a strap that holds a person into his or her seat in a car, truck, plane, or other vehicle, so that in a crash he or she would not be injured or killed by flying forward and hitting parts of the vehicle or being thrown out of it.

ACCIDENT
An accident is when something goes wrong when it is not meant to

FOSSIL FUEL
Fossil fuels are fuels that are hydrocarbons (molecules that have only hydrogen and carbon in them.)

MASS PRODUCTION
If an item is produced in large quantities, this is usually called mass production

A bus is a large wheeled vehicle meant to carry many different persons along with the driver

GASOLINE
Gasoline /slin/, or petrol /ptrl/, is a toxic, clear liquid that is mostly used as a fuel in internal combustion engines

A tram (tramcar, trolley, streetcar, or street railway) is a passenger vehicle that is like a light train

ETHANOL
Ethanol, also known as ethyl alcohol or grain alcohol, is a flammable, colorless chemical compound, one of the alcohols that is most often found in alcoholic drinks

CYLINDER
A cylinder is one of the most basic curved geometric shapes, with the surface formed by the points at a fixed distance from a given line segment, known as the axis of the cylinder

Traffic congestion is when vehicles travel at slower speeds because there are more vehicles than the road can handle

Anarchism is a political belief that is against authority, believing that people can organize themselves without needing state or a government in power.[1] Anarchists also believe that participation should never be forced by other people.

Poetry is a type of art form and a type of literature.

A drum is a musical instrument that is struck with the hands or with a drum stick (a stick for hitting a drum)

A clap is hitting your hands together that makes a sound

Cooking is a process to make food ready to eat by heating it

Johannes Brahms (7 May 1833 - 3 April 1897) was a famous German composer

MINIMALISM
Minimalism is a way of making modern art or music that uses simple ideas, sounds or shapes

A trumpet is a brass instrument used mainly in Classical music and jazz music

CHORD
A chord in music is when two or more notes are played together (some text books say that it is when three or more notes are played).

Repetition is a rhetorical device where words are used a number of times to emphasize something in literature or maybe even poems and rhymes

Serialism is a way of composing music using a series of notes in a particular order and using this to build up a whole piece of music

ROMANTIC MUSIC
Romantic music is music written in the 19th century

LOUDSPEAKER

A concert (as in a "concert tour") is a performance in which a musician or many musicians play music together to a group of listeners (an audience)

Sociology is the study of societies and how humans act in groups

NATURALISM (PHILOSOPHY)
Naturalism is "the idea or belief that nothing exists beyond the natural world".[1] It is the belief that "the natural world is the whole of reality".[2] The term was first used this way in English in 1477.[3]

ARGUMENT FROM INCONSISTENT REVELATIONS
The Argument from inconsistent revelations (also known as Avoiding the wrong hell problem) is an argument that says that God probably does not exist

Philosophical skepticism (Greek  - skepsis meaning "enquiry") is a school of philosophical thought that began in Ancient Greece[1] and a method that crosses many different cultures

ONTOLOGY
Ontology is a house within philosophy's major branch metaphysics, which is theory of reality

ARGUMENT FROM NONBELIEF
The Argument from nonbelief is a philosophical argument that says that God probably does not exist

PROBLEM OF EVIL
The problem of evil is the question whether evil exists, and if so does it disprove the existence of God.[1] Certain religions say there is a god who is all-loving, all-knowing and all-powerful

EARLY CHRISTIANITY
Early Christianity is known as the Christianity of around the three centuries (1st, 2nd, 3rd, early 4th) between the time of the Crucifixion of Jesus (c.26-36) and the First Council of Nicaea in 325.

LEAP OF FAITH
A Leap of faith commonly refers to believing something that cannot be touched or proved by science, for which there is no evidence

Epistemology [1] is the philosophy of knowledge.[2] It seeks to answer the questions "What is knowledge?" and "How is knowledge acquired?"

People use the word sacred or the word holy for something that a religion says is special or important.

DENOMINATION
Denomination could mean:

CRUSADES
When the Crusades happened, Muslims controlled the Holy Land

MONOTHEISM
Monotheism is the belief in only one god, rather than two or more, which would be polytheism

NONTRINITARIANISM
Nontrinitarism is a movement within Christianity

THEOLOGY
Theology is the study of one or more religions ("Theo-" means God in Greek and "-logy" is study, which makes it "God study" or "study of God")

LENT
Lent, in the Christian tradition, is the period of nearly five weeks before Easter.

COVENANT
A covenant is a formal agreement, a promise made made between two people.[1] It is often used as a religious promise

PAUL THE APOSTLE
Paul of Tarsus, also known as Saint Paul the Apostle, (AD 967) was a Messianic Jewish-Roman, Turkish writer and rabbi

RITUAL
A ritual (or a rite) is a set of actions people do

21ST CENTURY

The 21st century began on January 1, 2001, and will end on December 31, 2100.

PENANCE
Penance is repentance of sins, as well as the name of the Catholic Sacrament of Penance and Reconciliation/Confession

ASCENSION OF JESUS
According to the New Testament, the Ascension of Jesus happened at the end of Jesus' life on earth

FILIOQUE CLAUSE
The Filioque clause is a part of the Nicene Creed that not all Christians agree about

TOAST
Toast is bread which has been grilled until hot and crispy either using a toaster, a grill or rarely a flamethrower

IMMORTALITY
Immortality or eternal life is the idea of something which is alive that will stay alive forever

INCARNATION (CHRISTIANITY)
The Incarnation is the Christian belief that Jesus Christ is the God of Israel in a human body

SEVENTH-DAY ADVENTIST CHURCH
The Seventh-day Adventist Church is a Protestant Christian group

DIVINE GRACE
In Christianity Divine Grace means a favour of God for humankind

NORTH AMERICA
North America is a continent in the Northern and Western halves of Earth

ATHANASIAN CREED
The Athanasian Creed is a Christian statement of faith

DAY OF JUDGMENT
In the Christian religion, The Day of Judgment is the day in the future when all people who are living or who have ever lived will be judged by God

COPTIC ORTHODOX CHURCH OF ALEXANDRIA
The Coptic Orthodox Church of Alexandria is the name for the largest Christian church in Egypt

PROVINCES AND TERRITORIES OF CANADA
Canada's land is composed of thirteen parts: ten provinces and three territories

REVELATION
Revelation is when something is made clear or obvious that was hidden before

DECADE
A decade (pronounce: DEK-aid) is a period of 10 years

NESTORIANISM
Nestorianism is a movement within Christianity

JESUS
Jesus (born sometime between 7 and 4 BC/BCE, killed between 30 and 34 AD/CE[note 1] in Jerusalem), also known as Jesus Christ or Jesus of Nazareth, is the central figure of the Christian religion

COOPERATION
Cooperation is when people work together to make their lives better, even though they are free to not work together, and receive little if any money for working together.

MIRACLE
A Miracle is an amazing, beneficial event that goes against (or at least seems to) the laws of nature

GOD IN CHRISTIANITY
In Christianity, one way people think of God is as a being that made everything and lives forever

DAY OF JUDGMENT
In the Christian religion, The Day of Judgment is the day in the future when all people who are living or who have ever lived will be judged by God

AGE OF DISCOVERY
The Age of Discovery or Age of Exploration was a period from the early 15th century and continuing into the early 17th century, during which European ships traveled around the world to search for new trading routes and partners.

ARMENIAN APOSTOLIC CHURCH
The Armenian Apostolic Church (Armenian:   ), also called the Armenian Orthodox Church or the Gregorian Church, is the world's oldest national church[1][2] and one of the most ancient Christian communities [3].

ARMINIANISM
Arminianism is a school of soteriological thought in Protestant Christian theology founded by the Dutch theologian Jacobus Arminius.

CALENDAR
A calendar is a tool used to decipher the time of an event and for planning things that have not happened yet

PONTIUS PILATE
Pontius Pilate [1] was the governor of the Roman province of Judaea from AD 26 until 36.

PEDAGOGY
Pedagogy is the art or science of being a teacher.

DISCIPLE (CHRISTIANITY)
In Christianity, the disciples were the students of Jesus during his ministry, which means only the Twelve Apostles, but the gospels speaks of different numbers of disciples

SECOND GREAT AWAKENING
The Second Great Awakening was a religious movement in the United States in the early and mid 1800s

TOTAL DEPRAVITY
Total depravity (also called total inability or total corruption) is a theological teaching that comes from Augustine's teachings on original sin

CHRISTIAN THEOLOGY
Christian theology is reasoned commentary concerning Christian faith

SECT
A sect is a small religious or political group that separates from a larger group

BOOKS OF THE BIBLE
The Books of the Bible are the different sections of the Bible

GOD THE FATHER
In many religions, the deity or God is called the Father.

JEHOVAH'S WITNESSES
Jehovah's Witnesses is a group with more than seven million members throughout the world

ANNIHILATIONISM
Annihilationism (also called conditional immortality) is something that some Christians believe

GOOD FRIDAY
Friday immediately preceding Easter Sunday

WESTERN UNITED STATES
The Western United Statescommonly referred to as the American&#160;West or simply The&#160;Westtraditionally refers to the westernmost states of the United States

SAINT VINCENT AND THE GRENADINES
Coordinates: 1310N 6114W / 13.167N 61.233W / 13.167; -61.233 (Saint Vicent and the Grenadines)

TROPICS
The tropics are the region of the Earth near to the equator and between the Tropic of Cancer in the northern hemisphere and the Tropic of Capricorn in the southern hemisphere

GULF OF MEXICO
The Gulf of Mexico is a round sea, called a gulf

ELECTROMAGNETISM
Electromagnetism is the study of the electromagnetic field

RESONANCE
In physics, resonance is the tendency of a system to vibrate with increasing amplitudes at some frequencies of excitation

SHORTWAVE RADIO
Shortwave radio is a name for radio broadcasting in the range of 3-30 megahertz, and for the radio receivers made to tune in broadcasts

SIGNAL
Signal, signals or signalling may refer to:

ANTENNA
An antenna or aerial is a metal device made to send or receive radio waves

TUBE
Tube may refer to:

CURRENT
Current could mean:

VOLTAGE
Voltage is the change in electric potential (meaning potential energy per unit charge) between two positions

MULTIPLICATION
Multiplication is an arithmetic operation for finding the product of two numbers

RATIO
A ratio between two or more quantities is a way of measuring their sizes compared to each other.

WAVE (PHYSICS)
A wave is a kind of change that moves from one place to another.

ELECTROMAGNETIC RADIATION
Electromagnetic waves are waves that contain an electric field and a magnetic field and carry energy

SPEED OF LIGHT
The speed of light is the speed at which light travels in empty space

GAMMA RAY
Gamma rays (-rays) are electromagnetic waves with the smallest wavelengths in the electromagnetic spectrum.[1] They were discovered in 1900 by Paul Villard, and named in 1903 by Ernest Rutherford.

INFRARED
Infrared (IR) radiation is a type of electromagnetic radiation (a wave with electricity) 

MICROWAVE
A microwave is a kind of high-frequency radio wave

HERTZ
The hertz (symbol: Hz) is a unit to measure frequency

CREST (PHYSICS)
A crest is the point on a wave with the greatest positive value or upward displacement in a cycle

SATELLITE
Satellite may mean one of these:

ELECTROMAGNETIC SPECTRUM
The electromagnetic (EM) spectrum is the range of all possible electromagnetic radiation

NATURE
The words nature and natural are used for all the things that are normally not made by humans

ARTIFICIAL
When something is artificial or man-made, it has been made by humans, not nature

LIGHT
Light is a type of energy

METRE
A metre (US spelling, meter) is the basic unit of length in the SI measurement system

INTERFERENCE
In physics, interference is something that happens when two or more waves are in the same space

X-RAY
The X-ray is a type of ray in the electromagnetic spectrum that has more energy than ultraviolet radiation

MOBILE PHONE
A mobile phone (also known as a wireless phone, cell phone, or cellular telephone[1]) is a little portable radio telephone.

ATMOSPHERE OF EARTH
Earth's atmosphere is the layer of gases around the Earth

SOLAR WIND
The Solar Wind is wind from the sun

NASA
NASA or the National Aeronautics and Space Administration is the part of the United States government that deals with space exploration and aeronautics, the operating and designing of planes

PROXIMA CENTAURI
Proxima Centauri is a red dwarf star that is likely a part of the Alpha Centauri star system and is the closest star to the Sun at a distance of 4.22 light-years (3.991013&#160;km; 2.481013&#160;mi) light years

ASTRONAUT
An astronaut or cosmonaut is a person who goes into outer space

3D
3D (or 3-D) means three-dimensional, or having three dimensions

VOID (ASTRONOMY)
In astronomy, voids are the empty spaces between filaments

INTERSTELLAR MEDIUM
In astronomy, the interstellar medium (sometimes called the ISM) is the mix of plasma, gas, and dust in outer space between the stars of a galaxy

TELESCOPE
A telescope is an important tool for astronomy that gathers and focuses light

DIMENSION
Dimensions are a concept from mathematics and physics: One way to define a dimension is to look at the degrees of freedom a movement has in in a specific space

SPACE PROBE
A space probe is an unmanned space mission, usually a small spacecraft sent out to find out information about a planet

ASTRONOMICAL OBJECT
Astronomical object refers to any body or structure in the Observable universe which modern science has been able to determine exists

STAR
A star is a massive ball of plasma (very hot gas) held together by gravity

4D
4D (four dimensions) is an important idea in geometry.

ALBERT EINSTEIN
Albert Einstein (14 March 187918 April 1955)[1][2] was one of the most famous scientists of the 20th century.

EARTH'S MAGNETIC FIELD
The Earths magnetic field is the magnetic field that surrounds the Earth

VIDEO GAME CONSOLE
A video game console is a machine that is used to play video games

WIDESCREEN
Widescreen is a video format often used in movies

VIDEOCASSETTE RECORDER
Videocassette recorder (VCR) is an electronic device that records and plays videotapes

BOX
A box is a container used to put things in

PICTURE
A picture, also called an image, is a group of colored points on a flat surface that looks the same as something else

VIDEO CD
A Video CD or VCD is a CD that contains a movie instead of music or a computer program

CATHODE RAY TUBE
The cathode ray tube or CRT was invented by Karl Ferdinand Braun

SIGNAL (ELECTRICAL ENGINEERING)
In the fields of communications, signal processing, and in electrical engineering more generally, a signal is any time-varying quantity.

LIQUID CRYSTAL DISPLAY
A liquid crystal display is a special thin flat panel that can let light go through it, or can block the light

BROADCASTING

MOVIE THEATER
A movie theatre is a place where movies are shown on a big screen

SCREEN

PLASMA DISPLAY

Televisions with plasma display are much thinner than cathode ray tubes and are usually higher definition.

DVD
A DVD (which means Digital Versatile Disc or a Digital Video Disc) is an optical disc capable of storing up to 4.7 GB of data, more than six times what a CD can hold

ORGANIC LIGHT-EMITTING DIODE
Organic light-emitting diode (OLED) is a type of light-emitting diode (LED)

CABLE TELEVISION
Cable television is a way of letting people watch television without having to get signals from an antenna

IEEE 802.11
IEEE 802.11 is the name for a series of protocols for wireless networking

ORTHOGONAL FREQUENCY-DIVISION MULTIPLEXING
Orthogonal Frequency Division Multiplexing is a technology related to Frequency Division Multiplexing

CABLE

BLUETOOTH
Bluetooth is a protocol for wireless communication

LOCAL AREA NETWORK
A local area network (LAN) is a group of computers (network) in a small area like a home, office, or school

PARKES, NEW SOUTH WALES
Parkes is a city in New South Wales, Australia

APOLLO 11
Apollo 11 was the first mission organised to send people to the moon

TELEGRAPH
Telegraphy (from the Greek words tele () = far and graphein () = write) is the long-distance transmission of written messages without physical transport of letters.

In communications, such as radio and television, broadcasting means sending information such as television shows or music electronically to a large audience

ENTERTAINER

RADIO CONTROL

MICROWAVE
A microwave is a kind of high-frequency radio wave

NEWS
News is when people talk about current events (things that are happening right now)

DIFFRACTION
Diffraction is a physics concept

ADVERTISING
Advertising is how a company encourages people to buy their products, services or ideas

FIREFIGHTER
Firefighters or firemen are people whose job is to put out fires and rescue people

SOAP OPERA

RADIUS

ORBIT
An orbit is the path that an object takes in space when it goes around a star, a planet, or a moon

NORTH AMERICAN AEROSPACE DEFENSE COMMAND
North American Aerospace Defense Command (NORAD) is a joint organization of Canada and the United States that provides aerospace warning and defense for North America.[1] It was founded on May 12, 1958, as the North American Air Defense Command

UNITED STATES DEPARTMENT OF DEFENSE
The United States Department of Defense, also known as the DoD, is a department in the United States government that is in charge of the military of the United States

WATERWAY
A waterway is any body of water that can be used for transportation by people in boats

NAVIGATION
Navigation is how ships or aircraft find their way from one place to another

A restaurant is a place where food is sold to the public.

WRISTWATCH

RONALD REAGAN
Ronald Wilson Reagan (how to say: /rnld wlsn ren/; February 6, 1911  June 5, 2004) was the 40th President of the United States from 1981 to 1989 and the 33rd Governor of California from 1967 to 1975.

GALILEO GALILEI
Galileo Galilei [1] (15 February 1564  8 January 1642)[2] was an Italian astronomer, and instrument maker.[3] He ran into conflict with the Catholic Church of his day, and was put on trial for heresy by the Inquisition.

AIR NAVIGATION
Air navigation is special kind of general navigation

INITIALISM
An initialism is a word made from the first letters of each word in a phrase

The Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) is an agency of the United States Department of Transportation with authority to regulate and oversee all aspects of civil aviation in the U.S

HERTZ
The hertz (symbol: Hz) is a unit to measure frequency

COMPUTER NETWORK
A computer network is a group of computers connected to each other electronically

CABLE MODEM
A cable modem is a modem that can be used to deliver (usually digital) data over Cable television infrastructure

DIAL-UP
Dial-up internet access, usually just called Dial-up, is a slow way of connecting to the Internet by using a telephone line

ALEXANDER GRAHAM BELL
Alexander Graham Bell (March 3, 1847 - August 2, 1922) was a teacher, scientist, and inventor

A computer keyboard is an important device that allows a person to enter symbols like letters and numbers into a computer

NETWORK
A network is a group of things that are connected together using some form of talking or other communication to transfer information or data

ETHERNET
Ethernet is a way of connecting computers together in a local area network or LAN

TOUCHSCREEN
A touchscreen or touch screen is a screen that you can touch with your finger or a stylus pen to use, instead of or with a mouse and keyboard

E-MAIL
Electronic mail (or e-mail or email) is an Internet service that allows those people who have an e-mail address (accounts) to send and receive electronic letters

MOTOROLA
Motorola was a company that makes cell phones and other electronics

INTEGRATED CIRCUIT
An integrated circuit (more often called an IC, microchip, silicon chip, computer chip, or chip) is a piece of specially prepared silicon (or another semiconductor) into which a very complex electronic circuit is etched using photographic techniques

KILOBIT
A kilobit is 1000 (kilo-), as in SI, bits.[1] A bit is either 0 (off) or 1 (on)

DIGITAL SUBSCRIBER LINE
DSL (for Digital Subscriber Loop or Digital Subscriber Line) is the base for a number of technologies used to transmit digital data over a telephone line

MEGABIT
A megabit is a unit of information or computer storage

GLOBAL POSITIONING SYSTEM
A Global Positioning System, also known as GPS, is a system designed to help navigate on the Earth, in the air, and on water.

VIDEO GAME
Video games are electronic games played on a video screen (normally a television, a built-in screen when played on a handheld machine, or a computer).

Sonar is a machine that uses underwater sound waves to find other objects in the sea

KOREAN WAR
The Korean War( ) was a war fought in Korea between armies from North Korea and from South Korea

BATTLESHIP
A battleship is a large armored warship with a main battery consisting of heavy caliber guns

ATTACK ON PEARL HARBOR
The Attack on Pearl Harbor was a surprise attack by Japan against the United States naval base at Pearl Harbor, Hawaii on the morning of December 7, 1941

MISSILE
In general, missile may refer to any thrown or launched object aimed at a target

TOTALITARIANISM
Totalitarianism is a word used to describe modern regimes (political systems) where the government controls every part of public and private behavior, including the way that people think, behave, and talk

BATTLE OF STALINGRAD
The Battle of Stalingrad is a battle fought during the Second World War between Nazi Germany and the Soviet Union

PHONEY WAR
The Phoney War was a name of months after Poland was defeated in September 1939 and before France was invaded in May 1940, during World War II.

JOSIP BROZ TITO
Josip Broz, nicknamed Tito, (May 25, 1892  May 4, 1980) was the leader of the Socialist Federal Republic of Yugoslavia, from 1945 until his death.[1][2] From 1945 to 1953 he was Prime Minister, and from 1953 to 1980 he was the President

The Don () is one of the major rivers of Russia

REICHSTAG FIRE
The Reichstag fire (German: Der Reichstagsbrand) was an arson (setting fire) on the Reichstag building, place of meeting of German Parliament, in Berlin on 27 February 1933

The Allied Powers (or Allies of World War II) were a group of nations that fought against the Axis countries in World War II, later named the United Nations by U.S

Jet aircraft are aircraft with jet engines

MANCHUKUO
Manchukuo was a Japanese puppet state in Manchuria and eastern Inner Mongolia ruled by the former Emperor of China Henry Pu-yi

The Molotov-Ribbentrop Pact was signed by Vyacheslav Molotov (Russian foreign minister) and Joachim von Ribbentropp (German foreign minister) on 23 August, 1939

PUPPET STATE
A puppet state is a country that is officially independent, but not in practice

WARSHIP
A warship is a ship carrying weapons, which is used by the navy

DUNKIRK EVACUATION
The Dunkirk evacuation sometimes called Operation Dynamo or The Miracle at Dunkirk was a British mission to rescue Allied soldiers from the beaches of Dunkirk France, from 26 May and 4 June 1940

SOCIALIST STATE
A Socialist state, sometimes (though incorrectly)[source?] known as a communist state, is a country that practices a form of economics where productive property (companies) is owned by the state

BARREL
Barrel is an old English word for a big holder of liquids, such as petrol, beer, wine or oil

STRATEGIC BOMBING
Strategic bombing is a military strategy used to destroy the enemies' economic ability to fight a war

BIOLOGICAL WEAPON
A biological weapon is a weapon (usually a bomb) that uses germs to hurt people.

IRREDENTISM
Irredentism is the desire of a state, or of some people in a state, for annexation of land that another state has

SOUTHEAST ASIA
Southeast Asia or Southeastern Asia is the southeastern part of Asia

SUDETENLAND
The Sudetenland was a mountainous area of Czechoslovakia

NANKING MASSACRE
The Nanking Massacre was a genocide that took place in Nanjing, China during the Second World War

AXIS COUNTRIES
Axis countries and Axis Powers are the names for some countries that fought together against the Allies during World War II

THEATRE (WARFARE)
In warfare, a theatre or theater is an area where there are many battles

CEASEFIRE
A ceasefire (or truce) is a stoppage of a war or any armed conflict, where each side of the conflict agrees with the other to stop aggressive actions for some time

Operation Sea Lion (German: Unternehmen Seelwe) was the plan to invade the United Kingdom by the Nazis during World War II

A circadian rhythm is a rhythm that repeats about every 24 hours

The Solnhofen limestone is the world's most famous fossil site

Calcite is one of the most widely distributed minerals on the Earth's surface

Polyps are one of two forms of the cnidarians

WEATHERING
Weathering is the breaking down of rocks, soils and their minerals through direct contact with the Earth's atmosphere, waters, or living things.

The bivalves are a large class of molluscs, also known as pelecypods.

COCCOLITH
Coccoliths are the microscopic plates which form chalk

Glass is a hard material that can be made in many shapes

Red algae are members of the phylum Rhodophyta, a large group of aquatic algae with approximately 6000 species

A carbonate is a chemical compound that is made of carbon and oxygen

Sedimentary rocks are rocks formed from sediment

DOPING
Doping is either a term to describe drug use (usually illegal), or the process of putting certain types of chemical elements in a semiconductor in order to make their characteristics different.

An ICAO code is the code used by pilots and air traffic controllers to identify airports simply and easily.

A circus is a special kind of entertainment that can be enjoyed by children and adults

The Gallo-Romance branch of Romance languages includes French and several other languages spoken in modern France and northern Italy and Spain

BROWN
Brown is the color that is made when gray or black is mixed with orange, red, or rose (Brown is not a color of light, and mixing all the colors of light together gives white).

Acryl is a name for a number of chemical compounds that have an acrylic group, or of polymers of these compounds

The cinema of India includes movies produced in India

INDIAN INDEPENDENCE MOVEMENT
The Indian independence movement was a movement from 1857 (in many cases, even pre-dating 1857) until August 15, 1947, when India got independence from the British Raj

BOMBAY STOCK EXCHANGE
The Bombay Stock Exchange is a stock exchange in Mumbai, India.

Navi Mumbai is a planned satellite city of Mumbai, on the west coast of Maharashtra in India

The National Stock Exchange of India Limited (NSE), is a Mumbai-based stock exchange

The seven islands of Bombay are a group of islands very close to each other

Drizzle is the name given to light rain

An updraft or downdraft is the vertical movement of air as weather causes two forces to move.

CONDUCTION
Conduction in science is when energy moves from one place to another place by touch

WARM FRONT
A warm front is a leading edge of an advancing mass of warm air

A landslide includes a wide range of ground movement, such as rock falls, deep failure of slopes and shallow debris flows.

The dew point is the temperature where water vapour condenses into liquid water.

A metre (US spelling, meter) is the basic unit of length in the SI measurement system

A rain shadow is an area of land that lies behind a mountain which gets almost no rainfall

In geography, temperate latitudes of the Earth lie between the tropics and the polar circles

COMMON YEAR STARTING ON SUNDAY
This is the calendar for any common year starting on Sunday, January 1 (dominical letter A) or for any year in which Doomsday is Tuesday.
Examples: Gregorian years 1989, 1995, 2006, 2017 and 2023[1] or Julian year 1917

ROMAN NUMERAL
A Roman numeral is the name for a number when it is written in the way the Romans used to write numbers

Denim (which gets its name from the French town of Nmes (de Nmes)) is a very robust kind of textile

Jeans are a type of pants made from heavy, strong cotton material (fabric) called denim

KNITTING
Knitting creates flexible fabric by looping thread or yarn together using two or more knitting needles or a knitting machine.

FELT
Felt is a type of cloth that is made by matting wool fibers, either with water and soap, or by poking the fibers with barbed needles

Manufacturing is producing goods out of raw materials

LOGGING
Logging means cutting down trees

Hair is something that grows from the skin of mammals

The Industrial Revolution is the name historians have given to the period in history when there was a large and rapid change in the way things were made

MEDICAL DIAGNOSIS

A volcanic eruption occurs when gases and rocks are ejected from a volcano.

List of dormant volcanos includes the volcanos which scientists consider possible to erupt again.[1] A dormant volcano is "sleeping," but it could awaken in the future

Tuff (from Italian tufo) is a type of rock produced by the eruption of volcanoes.

In common speaking and geometry, a cone is a solid object that one gets when one rotates a right triangle around one of its two short sides, the cone's axis

Yellowstone National Park is a national park in the United States

STRATOVOLCANO
A stratovolcano is a tall, conical volcano built up by many layers (strata) of hardened lava, tephra, pumice, and volcanic ash.[1] Unlike shield volcanoes, stratovolcanoes have a steep slope and explosive eruptions every now and then.

MOUNT RAINIER
Mount Rainier is a mountain 54 miles (87 kilometres) southeast of Seattle, Washington, in the United States

LIST OF EXTINCT VOLCANOS
List of extinct volcanos includes volcanos which scientists consider unlikely to erupt again.[1] A volcano which has not erupted in the past 10,000 years is extinct.[2]

FELSIC
The word "felsic" is a term used in geology to refer to silicate minerals, magma, and igneous rocks which are enriched in the lighter elements such as silicon, oxygen, aluminium, sodium, and potassium.

MAFIC
Mafic is an adjective describing a silicate mineral or igneous rock which is rich in magnesium and iron

FLOOD BASALT
A flood basalt or trap basalt is the result of a giant volcanic eruption or series of eruptions that coats large stretches of land or the ocean floor with basalt lava.

INTERNATIONAL ORGANIZATION
An international organization is an organization, but rather than having people as members, they have individual countries as members

THE GUARDIAN
The Guardian is a British newspaper

JAMES BROWN
James Brown (May 3, 1933  December 25, 2006) was an American R&amp;B and funk singer.[1] He was known as the "Godfather of Soul", not to be confused with Marlon Brando's character in the movie The Godfather

THE DEVIL WEARS PRADA(FILM)
The Devil Wears Prada is a 2006 comedy-drama film, a loose screen adaptation of Lauren Weisberger's 2003 novel of the same name

THE WALL STREET JOURNAL
The Wall Street Journal (WSJ) is an international newspaper published every day by a company called Dow Jones &amp; Company

MERYL STREEP
Meryl Streep (June 22, 1949) is an American actress

UNITED STATES PRESIDENTIAL ELECTION, 2008
Electoral college votes for 2008

INTELLECTUAL PROPERTY
Intellectual property (IP) refers to the ownership of an idea or design by the person who came up with it

BETTE DAVIS
Bette Davis (April 5, 1908 - October 5, 1989) was an American actress of the stage, cinema and television

ISO 3166-1
ISO 3166-1, is part of the ISO 3166 standard

LIST OF COUNTRY CALLING CODES
The following is a list of country calling codes

CHEESE ANALOGUE
Cheese analogues are substitutes of cheese that are made to imitate the taste and the look of real cheese

TEXTURE
The word texture means: what things are made of and how they feel

VINEGAR
Vinegar is a liquid used mostly in cooking

CURD
Curds are a dairy product made by curdling milk with rennet or yeast so that it separates, and taking away the liquid part (called whey).[1][2] Milk that has been left to go sour will also naturally separate into curds and whey

VEGETARIANISM
Vegetarianism is the practice of not eating meat or fish

CREAM
Cream (also called milkfat, milk fat, and butterfat) is the fatty part of regular milk

STYLE
Style may refer to:

PASTEURIZATION
Pasteurization (or pasteurisation) is a process of making foods stay fresh

MOULD
Mould (or mold) is a type of tiny fungus

RENNET
Rennet is a meat derivative used in things like suet, suet makes dumplings

NAZI PARTY
&#160; Far right [2][3][4]

LUFTWAFFE
The Luftwaffe (pronounced IPA: ['luft..f]) is the name for the air force of Germany.

DIETRICH BONHOEFFER
Dietrich Bonhoeffer (4 February 1906  9 April 1945) was an important Lutheran pastor from Germany who was killed by the Nazis during World War II

HEINRICH HIMMLER
Heinrich Himmler (7 October 1900 - 23 May 1945) was the leader of Germany's SS and Gestapo organisation

MARTIN BORMANN
Martin Ludwig Bormann (17 June 1900 in Halberstadt  2 May 1945 in Berlin) was a German politician and member of the NSDAP

ENCYCLICAL
An Encyclical originally was a letter sent by a bishop to all churches of a particular area

ALFRED ROSENBERG
Alfred Rosenberg (12 January 1893 in Tallinn  16 October 1946 in Nuremberg) was an intellectual member of the NSDAP

CIDER
Cider (or cyder) is a drink made from fruit juice, most often from apples.

LIVAROT CHEESE
Livarot is a cheese from Normandy

CAMEMBERT CHEESE
Camembert cheese, more generally known as Camembert, is a French soft cheese

PETROCHEMICAL
Petrochemicals are chemical products that are made from petroleum, natural gas or other hydrocarbons.

DRUG
According to the WHO, a drug is a substance that can change how a living organism works

MAINE (PROVINCE)
Maine is a region and one of the traditional provinces of France

RUDOLPH OF FRANCE
Rudolph (also Radulf, Ralph, or Raoul) (c

COUNT
A count is a nobleman in most of European countries, equivalent in rank to a British earl, whose wife is also still a "countess" (for lack of an Anglo-Saxon term)

HOUSE OF NORMANDY
The House of Normandy is the usual name for the family that were the Dukes of Normandy and Kings of England

FIEFDOM
In feudalism, a fiefdom (also called a fief, feud, feoff, or fee) was a property or right that an overlord gave a vassal in exchange for military service

CHARLES THE SIMPLE
Charles III (17 September 879  7 October 929), called the Simple or the Straightforward (from the Latin Carolus Simplex),[a] was the King of the Franks from 898 until 922 and the King of Lotharingia from 911 until 91923

WILLIAM I, DUKE OF NORMANDY
William I Longsword (c.900942) was the second "Duke of Normandy".[a] William added to his father's territories

JACOBITISM
Jacobitism was (and, to a much smaller extent, is) the political movement that tried to put the Stuart kings back onto the thrones of England, Scotland, and Kingdom of Ireland

OCTOBER 14
2013 Calendar

SPANISH ARMADA
The Spanish Armada was a Spanish navy fleet most famous for being used by Spain's King Philip II to attack Britain in 1588

LIST OF ENGLISH MONARCHS
This is a list of the Kings and Queens of the Kingdom of England from 924 until England and Scotland joined together in 1707.

JERSEY
Jersey is an island off the northwest coast of France

BARBARY COAST
The Barbary Coast, or Berber Coast, was the land of the Berber people

AHMED BEN BELLA
Ahmed Ben Bella (25 December 1918[1]  11 April 2012) was an Algerian soldier

MATHEMATICIAN
A mathematician is someone who studies mathematics, either as a hobby or as a job

The National Liberation Front is a socialist political party in Algeria

Tipaza is a town on the coast of Algeria

PRESIDENT OF ALGERIA
The President of Algeria is the head of state of Algeria

HAMMADID
The Hammadids were a Berber group

WORLD HERITAGE SITE
World Heritage Sites are places in the world which are very important from the cultural or natural point of view

COLONY
A colony is a place controlled by another country

ENGLISH LANGUAGE
English is a West Germanic language that was first spoken in Anglo-Saxon England in the early Middle Ages

STATE
In modern politics, a state is an association which has control over a geographic area or territory

ATOMIC NUCLEUS
